answers.body_markdown:
You can put your desired function in another place and call it when needed. From what I understood, the function is not yet bound to your element because it doesn't exist in the DOM yet (when it loads), so the JavaScript won't find the element when the document is ready, only when an specific event triggers the creation of the element.

Try setting your function _outside_ of `$(document).ready` and bind it to an element in another event that you know will be called _after_ the element is actually in the DOM.

Hope this answer helps!

answers.title: Query to match primary key from Customer table and CustomerCard based on CustomerEmail and CustomerCardNumber?

answers.body_markdown:
Unfortunately, Oracle does not support the `UPDATE ... JOIN ... SET` syntax. Instead, you can use a subquery to recover the customer id from the email:

    UPDATE CustomerCards
    SET 
        expirationMonth = :expirationMonth
        expirationyear  = :expirationYear
    WHERE
        CardNumber = :cardNumber
    	AND cc.CustomerId = (SELECT CustomerId FROM Customers c WHERE email = :email)

This assumes that there an email uniquely identify a customer.

The query expects 4 parameters:

- `:cardNumber` and `:email` are used to identify the record to update
- `:expirationMonth` and `:expirationYear` are the vaues to assign

If it is to select columns of same name

    library(dplyr)
    my_tibble %>%
         select(starts_with('a'))


---

Or if we are interested in combining the 1st 4 columns as a single column, next 4 as 2nd, then use `split`, and convert it to a `data.frame`

    out <- data.frame(lapply(split.default(my_tibble, rep(c('a', 'a1'), 
               each = 4)), unlist))
    row.names(out) <- NULL

    out
    #   a a1
    #1  1  4
    #2  2  3
    #3  3  2
    #4  4  1
    #5  2  5
    #6  3  4
    #7  4  3
    #8  5  2
    #9  3  6
    #10 4  5
    #11 5  4
    #12 6  3
    #13 4  7
    #14 5  6
    #15 6  5
    #16 7  4


---

If it is based on the occurrence of 'a' as the prefix in column name

    grp <- cumsum(startsWith(names(my_tibble), 'a'))

answers.body_markdown:
>sleep for d minutes if required

You can't "sleep" the consumer thread for more than `max.poll.interval.ms`.

The whole point of pausing the container is so that it continues to `poll` (but will never get any new records until resumed).

If you actually sleep the listener there is no point in pausing; you just need to increase th `max.poll.interval.ms` appropriately.

From the docs:

https://docs.docker.com/engine/swarm/swarm-tutorial/#open-protocols-and-ports-between-the-hosts

The following ports must be available. On some systems, these ports are open by default.

- TCP port 2377 for cluster management communications
- TCP and UDP port 7946 for communication among nodes
- UDP port 4789 for overlay network traffic

If you plan on creating an overlay network with encryption (--opt encrypted), you also need to ensure ip protocol 50 (ESP) traffic is allowed.

**Notes**  

- Exposing these ports to the internet poses significant security risks
- Performance of an overlay network between two separate data centers will suffer.

answers.body_markdown:
When you create a new project and react-native version >=60 , this line is automatically added in pod file ([official site][1])

```
# example/ios/Podfile
require_relative '../../node_modules/@react-native-community/cli-platform-ios/native_modules'

```

This is path of script , so when you run "pod install" , it will check all libraries and install all pods files required 


**So when you add new library , no lines are added to my Podfile but you have to run "pod install" so that script file can run and install new pod files .**

Please do not use manual linking as described in [official site][1] 

> This means that all libraries need to ship a Podspec either in the
> root of their folder or where the Xcode project is. Podspec references
> the native code that your library depends on.
> 
> The implementation ensures that a library is imported only once. If
> you need to have a custom pod directive then include it above the
> use_native_modules! function.

**You have to do 2 steps**

1 : Add library **"yarn add react-native-gesture-handler"**

2 : cd ios && pod install


  [1]: https://github.com/react-native-community/cli/blob/master/docs/autolinking.md

answers.body_markdown:
Obviously your string has a decimal part, hence you cannot cast it directly to an integer.

A solution would be to first `CAST` to a floating point number, and then to an integer, like:

    SELECT CAST( CAST([BR] AS FLOAT) AS INT) AS CC FROM [Seg].[dbo].[pro_ben]

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=sqlserver_2017&fiddle=2098d2263007a43f10b3e1a1e85b767e)**:

    SELECT CAST('3893.768' AS FLOAT)

<pre>
| (No column name) |
| ---------------: |
|         3893.768 |
</pre>

    SELECT CAST( CAST('3893.768' AS FLOAT) AS INT)

<pre>
| (No column name) |
| ---------------: |
|             3893 |
</pre>
answers.title: conversion varchar to int issues

answers.body_markdown:
The value is not an integer.  This leaves you with various options:

- You could use `try_convert()` which would return `NULL`.
- You can use an intermediate data type and then convert to the final data type, but you might lose precision (under some circumstances).
- You could convert to a `numeric()` instead.

Conversion to a `numeric` ignores decimal points, but they do not cause an error:

    SELECT convert(numeric(10,0), [BR]) as dd
    FROM [Seg].[dbo].[pro_ben];

You can then convert to an `int` if you specifically need that type.

It depends. Queues are included in freeRTOS because they are required for task switching and other core OS features to work. If you are getting low on storage space (flash memory), it may make sense to use the "free" (as in, it's going to already be there) implementation in freeRTOS. If you are in somewhat of a timecrunch and you have plenty of flash, I'd just keep with what works. If you've tested it and it works, keep using it.

items.body_markdown:
It appears that JGit does not offer path filters that support Ant-style or glob patterns.

- `PathFilter` filters for full paths such as `child-project/foo.txt`
- `PathSuffixFilter` (e.g. `.txt`) filters for path suffixes _in any intermediary path_ (catch-all) such as `foo.txt`, `child-project/foo.txt`, or `child-project/src/resources/foo.txt`

Hence, if you want to filter for `child-project/*.txt` - but not `child-project/src/*.txt` - you're out of luck.

I don't see the logic behind offering exactly these two path filters when offering _just a single one_ that would support Ant-style or glob patterns would cover all cases.

The documentation in `PathSuffixFilter` hints

> Using this filter is recommended instead of filtering the entries using `TreeWalk.getPathString()` and `endsWith` or some other type of string match function.

To me one doesn't rule out the other. What could be the reason behind that choice?
items.title: JGit path filter to support Ant-style or glob patterns

answers.body_markdown:
The problem is in this line:

    docs_dict.filter_extremes(no_below=20, no_above=0.2)

`no_below=20` means that all tokens with a count of less than 20 in the whole corpus will be deleted from the dictionary. 
`no_above=0.2` means that all tokens that occur in more than 20 percent of your documents will be deleted from the dictionary. 
Since you only used a toy document set for the example, all of your tokens will be filtered. Just comment the line while using the toy document set.

df = pd.read_csv(StringIO(data), index_col=[0], sep=" ", skipinitialspace=True)

answers.body_markdown:
You could use [apply](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.apply.html) combined with [collections.Counter](https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html#collections.Counter):

    import pandas as pd
    from collections import Counter
    
    data = [['abc', 'bca'],
            ['aab', 'aba'],
            ['abc', 'cabe']]
    
    df = pd.DataFrame(data=data, columns=['A', 'B'])
    
    df['C_A'] = df.A.apply(Counter)
    df['C_B'] = df.B.apply(Counter)
    
    mask = df.C_A == df.C_B
    print(mask)
**Output**

    0     True
    1     True
    2    False
    dtype: bool

Counter creates a dictionary with the counts of each letter in the string, eg:

    'abc' -> Counter({'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1})

Counters are equals if and only both the keys and the counts are equal, i.e, if and only if the strings are equals regardless of the order of the characters. This solution is `O(n)` for each string vs the sorted approach that is `O(n*logn)`.

Here's a snippet of the build output that shows the options I am using. I've tried a number of variations on the `mabi` option and removing `no-builtin`, but the output still isn't using the optimized `memset`.

When I enabled the linker map with `-Xlinker --print-map` I can see how the linker found an implementation for `memset`:

    /home/blah/tools/gcc-arm-none-eabi-8-2019-q3-update/bin/../lib/gcc/arm-none-eabi/8.3.1/../../../../arm-none-eabi/lib/thumb/v7e-m/nofp/libg.a(lib_a-memset.o)

    thumb/nofp;@mthumb@mfloat-abi=soft

    thumb/v7-m/nofp;@mthumb@march=armv7-m@mfloat-abi=soft
    thumb/v7e-m/nofp;@mthumb@march=armv7e-m@mfloat-abi=soft
    thumb/v7e-m+fp/softfp;@mthumb@march=armv7e-m+fp@mfloat-abi=softfp
    thumb/v7e-m+fp/hard;@mthumb@march=armv7e-m+fp@mfloat-abi=hard
    thumb/v7e-m+dp/softfp;@mthumb@march=armv7e-m+fp.dp@mfloat-abi=softfp
    thumb/v7e-m+dp/hard;@mthumb@march=armv7e-m+fp.dp@mfloat-abi=hard
    thumb/v8-m.base/nofp;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.base@mfloat-abi=soft
    thumb/v8-m.main/nofp;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.main@mfloat-abi=soft
    thumb/v8-m.main+fp/softfp;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.main+fp@mfloat-abi=softfp
    thumb/v8-m.main+fp/hard;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.main+fp@mfloat-abi=hard
    thumb/v8-m.main+dp/softfp;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.main+fp.dp@mfloat-abi=softfp
    thumb/v8-m.main+dp/hard;@mthumb@march=armv8-m.main+fp.dp@mfloat-abi=hard

The code in newlib is pretty difficult to grok, in `newlib/libc/machine/arm/aeabi_memset.c` I see:

    /* According to the run-time ABI for the ARM Architecture, this
       function is allowed to corrupt only the integer core register
       permitted to be corrupted by the [AAPCS] (r0-r3, ip, lr, and
       CPSR).
    
       Therefore, we can't just simply use alias to support the function
       aeabi_memset for the targets with FP register.  Instead, versions
       for these specific targets are written in assembler (in
       aeabi_memset-soft.S).  */
    
    /* NOTE: This ifdef MUST match the one in aeabi_memset-soft.S.  */
    #if !defined (__SOFTFP__)
    
    /* Defined in aeabi_memset-soft.S.  */
    
    #else
    /* Support the alias for the __aeabi_memset which may
       assume memory alignment.  */
    void __aeabi_memset4 (void *dest, size_t n, int c)
            _ATTRIBUTE ((alias ("__aeabi_memset")));
    
    void __aeabi_memset8 (void *dest, size_t n, int c)
            _ATTRIBUTE ((alias ("__aeabi_memset")));
    
    /* Support the routine __aeabi_memset.  Can't alias to memset
       because it's not defined in the same translation unit.  */
    void __aeabi_memset (void *dest, size_t n, int c)
    {
      /*Note that relative to ANSI memset, __aeabi_memset hase the order
        of its second and third arguments reversed.  */
      extern void memset (void *dest, int c, size_t n);
      memset (dest, c, n);
    }
    #endif

This means that if `__SOFTFP__` is defined you do not get optimized memset functions.

If I use the following compiler options `-mcpu=cortex-m3 -mthumb -mfloat-abi=softfp -march=armv7e-m+fp` then it should get the linker to pick up a `libg.a` with the optimized `memset` but CMSIS is mad at me for trying this and fails my build:

      #if defined (__VFP_FP__) && !defined(__SOFTFP__)
        #error "Compiler generates FPU instructions for a device without an FPU (check __FPU_PRESENT)"
      #endif

I guess this makes sense since the Cortex-M3 doesn't have a FPU. It seems newlib simply doesn't support assembly optimized memset unless you have an FPU? I am not clear on the reasoning they provide. When building my project I can override newlib with the optimized memset by building it locally, it seems to work but are there potential issues and what other performance optimizations might I be missing in newlib?

items.body_markdown:
I am creating an application in python which utilizes the current user's browser to execute javascript code. To do this I have created an extension, designed to work in both FireFox and Chrome, to facilitate the communication between the browser and the native application.

The extension must be able to execute javascript in the context of the current user's profile (not in a new profile), and work entirely in the background; so as to not disturb the user if they wish to use their web browser while my app runs.

The extension is invoked by attempting to navigate to a predefined URL. This navigation attempt is blocked, and the extension's initialization routine is subsequently executed.

My initial tests were done in FireFox, and I ran into a myriad of problems.

 1. FireFox will not allow me to embed another running instance of the browser as a subprocess, without running it in the context of a different user profile
 2. FireFox will not allow me to open a new window in a hidden state within the context of a currently-running instance.
 3. If FireFox happens to not be running, it *is* possible to run a hidden instance of the browser under my application, but prevents the user from creating another instance themselves (without first closing mine).

Additionally, I don't believe solutions such as [tabs.hide()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/API/tabs/hide) are valid, as the documentation reads: `The current active tab cannot be hidden`, which means I would have to create a hidden window, and now this loops back to problem number three above.

I have only looked briefly at this process in Chrome, but it seems to have many of the same problems. For example, you can create a new instance of Chrome by specifying a custom user directory, but then I would lose access to the data within the current user's session.

The simplest solution would be one which allows FireFox/Chrome to run another independent instance of the browser under the same user profile, but this doesn't seem to be possible.

Is there a solution to my problem which would work for both FireFox and Chrome, while still remaining cross platform?

Thank you.

Edit:
Added a more thorough explanation to the top of the post.
items.title: Independent browser instance under the same user profile

answers.body_markdown:
Use `EXISTS` and a correlated subquery:


    SELECT *
    FROM mytable t
    WHERE 
        t.letter = 'b'
        OR EXISTS (
            SELECT 1
        	FROM mytable t1
        	WHERE 
                t1.record_number != t.record_number 
                AND t1.external_id = t.external_id 
                AND t1.letter = 'b'
        )

Another option is to use a window function:

    
    SELECT record_number, external_id, letter
    FROM (
    	SELECT 
    		t.*,
    		MAX(CASE WHEN letter = 'b' THEN 1 END) OVER(PARTITION BY external_id) mx
    	FROM mytable t
    ) x WHERE mx = 1

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/?rdbms=sqlserver_2017&fiddle=240b5cd062d3306343681dadaabf1114)**:

<pre>
record_number | external_id | letter
------------: | ----------: | :-----
            1 |      123456 | a     
            2 |      123456 | b     
            3 |      123456 | c     
            4 |      456852 | t     
            5 |      456852 | b     
</pre>

answers.body_markdown:
> bash: syntax error near unexpected token `('

The char `(` is recognized by bash to be a bash token, so you would have to escape it, but that is not what you want. You want to pass the XPath expression to `xmllint`, so the solution is to put the expression in brackets:

    xmllint --xpath '//Hosts/Host[1]/@Host_FQDN' myFile.xml

Your second error was to _interrupt_ the `string(...)` function in the middle of your XPath expression. So a correct version of your attempts would look like

    xmllint --xpath "string(//Hosts/Host[1]/@Host_FQDN)" myFile.xml

The above expression returns only the string value of the first `Host` element's `Host_FQDN` attribute.

---

**Just some kind of a horrid note:**  
You used the `` quote char instead of the `"` quote char!!!  
That could have been a reason for your malfunctions as well.

answers.body_markdown:
The reason being is that you are concatenating two strings. You have `this.state.data` initially set to 5 in a string and the user input is also a string. This is tricky since JavaScript is a loosely-typed language. If you want to add the numbers together (5 + 10 = 15). You can do this:

 1. Initially set `this.state.data` to 5 without quotes so it is a number
 2. You should have another variable in state called something like `input`. In your `handleChange` method, you should just update this to `e.target.value`.
 3. In your `handleSubmit`, you would then convert `this.state.input` to a number and then add it with `this.state.data`. This should get you your answer.

The problem is that you are comparing bytearrays of different sizes in your conditional. Thus it will *always* evaluate to `False`. Change the upper bound to 4 so that you get 4 bytes instead.

```python
>>> result = b'\x00\x01\x02\x03\x89\x88\x88M'
>>> response[0:3] == bytearray(b'\x00\x01\x02\x03') # Your condition
False
>>> response[0:4] == bytearray(b'\x00\x01\x02\x03') # Better version
True
>>>
```
